coredata.dc:title: Ultrasound and microwave assisted-synthesis of ZIF-8 from zinc oxide for the adsorption of phosphate
coredata.prism:copyright: © 2022 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:creator: Bazzi, Loubna
Ayouch, Ikrame
Tachallait, Hamza
EL Hankari, Samir
coredata.dc:description: The conversion of solid matters into metal-organic frameworks has emerged as a new alternative for the synthesis of MOFs. Various synthesis methods have been applied for this transformation using wet-chemistry and solid-state methods to result in the formation of a mixture of MOFand oxide@MOF. Thus, it is highly desired to develop other methods to increase the MOF yield from oxide and accelerate the conversion rate. In this context, the use of ultrasound and microwave methods, known in the preparation of MOFs from metallic salts with an accelerated reaction time and enhanced yield, have surprisingly never been used in the transformation of oxides into MOFs. Herein we describe the conversion of zinc oxide to ZIF-8 in different solvent mixtures (DMF/water, methanol/water and water) under microwave (MW) and ultrasonic (US) irradiation. The results revealed different morphologies and particle sizes in different synthesis conditions and solvents with higher conversion rate using US over MW. The synthesized MOFs demonstrated excellent phosphate adsorption capacity, thereby giving them the potential to be used as effective adsorbent materials for wastewater treatment. This work opens up a new avenue toward the development of MOFs from other inorganic sustainable solid resources using US and MW.

head.ce:title: Ultrasound and microwave assisted-synthesis of ZIF-8 from zinc oxide for the adsorption of phosphate

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The conversion of solid matters into metal-organic frameworks has emerged as a new alternative for the synthesis of MOFs. Various synthesis methods have been applied for this transformation using wet-chemistry and solid-state methods to result in the formation of a mixture of MOFand oxide@MOF. Thus, it is highly desired to develop other methods to increase the MOF yield from oxide and accelerate the conversion rate. In this context, the use of ultrasound and microwave methods, known in the preparation of MOFs from metallic salts with an accelerated reaction time and enhanced yield, have surprisingly never been used in the transformation of oxides into MOFs. Herein we describe the conversion of zinc oxide to ZIF-8 in different solvent mixtures (DMF/water, methanol/water and water) under microwave (MW) and ultrasonic (US) irradiation. The results revealed different morphologies and particle sizes in different synthesis conditions and solvents with higher conversion rate using US over MW. The synthesized MOFs demonstrated excellent phosphate adsorption capacity, thereby giving them the potential to be used as effective adsorbent materials for wastewater treatment. This work opens up a new avenue toward the development of MOFs from other inorganic sustainable solid resources using US and MW.

ce:section.ce:para: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a new class of porous hybrid organic inorganic materials constructed by the interaction of metal cores and organic linkers [1–4]. They are known by their high surface area and tunable porosity allowing site accessibility and the diffusion of the adsorbate through the framework [5].

The surface areas of a typical MOFs range from 1000 to 10,000 m2/g [6], which can exceed those of traditional porous materials such as zeolites and carbons. MOFs and their composites have been applied in a wide spectrum of applications, mentioning drug delivery [7], gas storage [8], catalysis [9], luminescence sensing [10] and adsorption [11–13]. The latter is considered to be one of the simplest and cost-effective methods for the removal of many emergent organic and inorganic pollutants from water. Thus, the high surface area and permanent porosity of MOFs together with their amenability to be tuned, with respect to their functional richness regarding both organic and inorganic blocks make them special types of potential porous materials of great interest in adsorption applications [14–16]. Over the last decade, many researchers have used MOFs and MOF-based composites as potential adsorbents for the removal of phosphate from aqueous solutions [17–21].

Zeolite imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) constructed from Zn2+ as a metal center ion and imidazolate as organic ligand have been considered as one of the most used MOFs owing to their large specific surface area, unique structural flexibility, hydrophobic pore surface [22] and high chemical and thermal stability, allowing it to be used as an appropriate sorbent for different adsorption applications [23], and particularly in the adsorption of phosphate [24]. However, the synthesized ZIF-8 are usually prepared from zinc acetate and zinc nitrate precursors [25]. Although strategies using zinc oxide have emerged as a cheaper and sustainable alternative leading to water as a by-product [26], most of the works have focused on the conversion of zinc oxide nanorods, nanolayers and micron spherical particles into ZIF-8 thin films [27,28] micron spherical ZnO@ZIF-8 particles [29], but few studies have described the conversion of zinc oxide into ZIF-8 powder with non-reacted ZnO with 6–24 h reaction time [30–33]. Thus, strategies to increase the conversion rate and reduce the reaction time are highly desired.

US and MW irradiation are considered as the most inexpensive, and efficient nonconventional heating methods that have been widely investigated in the synthesis of different MOFs [34,35] as they have various advantages compared to conventional heating, from the degree of acceleration, phase-selective crystallization, and crystal size reduction [36].

To the best of our knowledge, these unconventional technologies using US and MW were never applied for the conversion of oxides into MOFs although their use in the synthesis of different MOFs using metallic precursors-based nitrate and acetate. Thus, their use in this ZnO transformation to ZIF-8 are expected to have a notable increase in the conversion rate and yield with a reduced reaction time. Therefore, the main focus of the current work is to study the effect of US and MW on the conversion of ZnO into ZIF-8 powder and the formed particle size, then showcases a new comparative study on the effect of US and MW. Furthermore, the synthesized materials prepared in DMF/water were selected as adsorbents for phosphate removal tests from aqueous medium. In our case, the US prepared MOFs showed higher conversion rate to ZIF-8 and higher dispersed ZIF-8 particles than their homologues prepared under MW. Although the MW showed a lower conversion rate, better regeneration of the material was observed owing to the presence of more uncovered ZnO and aggregation of particles.

All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources (Aldrich and VWR) and used as received without further purification. The solvents used for the synthesis were of analytical reagent grade. The synthesis of ZIF-8 was assisted by microwave irradiation and ultrasound. Three mixtures of solvent were used (deionized water/dimethylformamide) (W/D), (deionized water/methanol) (W/M) and (deionized water/deionized water) (W/W). In brief, 0,2 g ZnO and 0.8 g 2-methylimidazole (Hmim) were added separately into 15 mL of deionized water (W) and 15 mL of deionized water or DMF (D) or methanol (M). Then, the zinc oxide solution was added to Hmim solution, and the mixture was stirred for 10 min in ultrasonic bath before applying both microwave and ultrasound at 65 °C for 30 min to yield different materials named respectively ZIF-8-W-(US or MW), ZIF-8-WD-(US or MW) and ZIF-8-WM-(US or MW). The white color product was separated using centrifuge in 4000 rpm for 10 min and washed several times with deionized water.

The materials synthesized in water/DMF were chosen for the phosphate adsorption study owing to the higher conversion rate using water/DMF mixture. Adsorption studies were carried out in batch experiments. A phosphate stock solution with a concentration of 50 mg/L was first prepared and then diluted appropriately to the initial concentration required for each experiment. All experiments maintained the adsorbent dosage at 5 g/L, neutral pH, and temperature at 25 °C, unless specified. After the adsorption test, the adsorbent was separated from the adsorbate solution using a 0.22 μm microporous membrane. The concentration of orthophosphate ions was determined spectrophotometrically according to the colorimetric method reported by Abdellaoui et al. [37]. Orthophosphate anions were complexed with ammonium molybdate and potassium antimonyl tartrate to form a phosphomolybdic complex under acidic conditions. Thereafter, reduction of the formed complex to molybdenum blue was achieved using ascorbic acid. The concentration of molybdenum blue was determined using a JENWAY-6300 spectrophotometer at the wavelength of λ = 880 nm.

The adsorption capacity of the studied materials towards phosphate (q
e (mg/g)) was calculated using the following mass balance equation [38]:
q e
=
(
C 0
−
C e
)
V
m
where Co and Ce (mg/L) are the initial and equilibrium concentrations of phosphate ions, respectively, V (L) is the volume of the adsorbate solution, and m (g) is the mass of the adsorbent.

The effect of initial concentration and adsorption isotherms were carried out by varying the initial phosphate concentration from 1 to 50 mg/L and adsorption kinetics were conducted by varying the contact time from 5 to 360 min with an initial adsorbate concentration of 5 mg/L.

In order to elucidate the adsorption mechanisms that take place during the removal of phosphate ions by the investigated materials, experimental data modeling was applied to the adsorption isotherms and kinetics. In the case of the isotherms, the used models were Langmuir and Freundlich and Sips, while for the kinetics, pseudo-first order, pseudo-second order, Avrami fractionary order and intraparticle diffusion models, were applied (Tables 1 and 2
). All models were fitted using the non-linear fitting advantages of OriginPro 2018 software.where Ce (mg/L) is the adsorbate concentration at the equilibrium, kL (L/mg) the Langmuir affinity constant, Qmax (mg/g) is the maximum adsorption capacity of the material assuming a monolayer of adsorbate is taken by the adsorbent. kF (L/mg) is the Freundlich constant capacity and nf is the Freundlich exponent. kS is the Sips equilibrium constant (L/mg), and nS is the Sips model exponent.where qt and qe (mg/g) are the adsorbed amount at time t and the adsorption capacity in the equilibrium, respectively, kf, ks, kid, kAV are the pseudo-first-order, pseudo-second order, intraparticle diffusion and Avrami fractional order rate constants, respectively, and n is a fractional reaction order which can be related, to the adsorption mechanism [39].

One of the most prominent parameters that affect the adsorption behavior and capacity is the temperature of the medium. Therefore, in order to understand the course and feasibility of adsorption reaction, the temperature effect, and the thermodynamic parameters, including Gibbs free energy ΔG°, standard entropy ΔS° and standard enthalpy ΔH° at 298, 308, 318, 328 and 338 K were studied. These parameters were obtained by asserting that the pollutant is adsorbed in a porous material with a constant void fraction, resulting in a homogeneous dispersion at the surface [40]. The thermodynamic parameters were calculated using the Van't Hoff equation given below:
l n K =
−
Δ G °

In which,

is the equilibrium constant or the linear adsorption distribution coefficient, T is the solution temperature (K), and R is the gas constant (8.314 J/mol/K). ΔH° and ΔS° are calculated from the slope and intercept of the plot of lnK versus 1/T.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structural and morphological analysis of ZnO@ZIF-8
ce:section.ce:para:
The crystal structures of the synthesized powders by both MW and US were identified with XRD characterization which was performed to analyze the two phases of the as prepared materials and the results are displayed in Figs. 1 and 2
. The peak positions and sharp diffraction peaks of ZIF-8 were indexed in the range of 5–20°. The positions 7.38°, 10.38°, 12.77° and 14.70° and intensities of the diffraction peaks are compatible with ZIF-8 reported in the literature [41], while the peaks 31.84°, 34.52°, 36.38° and 47.64° are contributed to ZnO from the literature [42]. Consequently, our material can be considered as a composite of ZIF-8 and ZnO referred to as ZnO@ZIF-8: ZnO@ZIF-8-W-(US or MW), ZnO@ZIF-8-WD-(US or MW) and ZnO@ZIF-8-WM-(US or MW) made respectively in water, water/DMF and water/MeOH using US or MW.

If we compare the highest intensity of the formed ZIF-8 that appears at 2θ = 7.38° with that of the three highest peaks of ZnO at 2θ = 31.84°, 34.52°, 36.38°, we can conclude that the conversion yield of ZnO to ZIF-8 is higher in the case of ultrasounds compared to microwave for the same solvent mixture as can be clearly demonstrated by XRD peak intensity showing increased intensities of ZIF-8 peaks compared to their homologues prepared using MW. This can be explained by the cavities created by US in the in the liquid medium. These cavities (i.e., bubbles) can generate microchannels and microstirring on interfaces and mechanical phenomena [43], leading to the increased ZIF-8 particle detachment from ZnO and transport, creating new active surface on the ZnO to react with 2 methyl imidazole, consequently leading to the enhancement of ZnO conversion. Moreover, although the reaction undertaken in water using US showed higher conversion rate than W/D or W/M, additional peaks appeared in this case corresponding to Zn(OH)2 that are formed in water as reported in the previously published works, and the pure phase of ZIF-8 in an aqueous phase can be constructed by increasing the 2MIM ligand [44]. In the contrary, the MOFs prepared in water applying MW showed lower conversion rate compared to other solvent mixture: W/D or W/M.

Further investigations were carried out regarding the crystallite size and the crystallinity of the different composites. The intensity and width of the main peaks were used to estimate the crystal size of the different ZnO@ZIF-8 materials. The crystallinity of the materials was determined by the peak integration method on OriginPro and the crystallite sizes were calculated using Debye-Scherrer equation:
D =
k λ
B C o s θ
where D is the crystallite size (nm), K is a constant between 0.8 and 1,2 (0.9 in this work), λ is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation (CuKα = 0.1541 nm), β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the intense and broad peaks, and θ is the Bragg's or diffraction angle [45].

As shown in Fig. 3 , ZnO@ZIF-8 synthesized in water and US-assisted has the highest crystallinity with the biggest crystallite size around 22 nm. While ZnO@ZIF-8 using microwave with water as solvent showed the lowest crystallinity with a crystallite size around 20 nm. Consequently, the materials synthesized in water both with US and MW displayed the highest crystallite size. On the other hand, the crystallite size of ZnO@ZIF-8-WD-MW, ZnO@ZIF-8-WM-MW, ZnO@ZIF-8-WD-US and ZnO@ZIF-8-WM-US is 15 nm, 19 nm, 19 nm and 17 nm, respectively. Moreover, the crystallinity was found to be higher using ultrasound over microwave samples, as the ultrasound allow better dispersion of the reactional mixture.

The FTIR spectrums shown in Fig. 4 display the characteristic bonds of our MOFs. The absorption peaks at 1676, and 1586 cm−1 can be attributed to the skeleton vibration of the imidazole ring. The peak at 1590 cm−1 could be due to the CN stretch modes whereas the peaks at 1423 and 1382 cm−1 correspond to the entire ring stretching. Several spectral bands seen in the range 1311 to 900 cm−1 that could be ascribed to the in-plane bending of the ring and the peaks at 775 and 691 cm−1 were associated with aromatic sp2 C–H bending. Finally, a strong band at 421 cm−1 was observed that corresponds to the Zn–N stretching as the zinc atoms in the ZIF-8 structure connect to nitrogen atoms of 2-MeIm linker during the formation of ZIF-8 [46]. Moreover, the FTIR spectrums of the different synthesized materials in different solvents by ultrasound showed a narrow vibration mode at 421 cm−1, demonstrating a higher conversion of ZnO to ZIF-8 rather than microwave assisted MOFs as the vibration mode is broader. It can be explained by the mechanical effect of ultrasound, acting as the driving force behind the detachment of the ZIF-8 particles all along its formation on the surface of ZnO, allowing higher conversion rate.

The morphology of the different synthesized ZnO@ZIF-8 was determined using scanning electron microscope (SEM) as shown in Fig. 5 . The different solvents and synthesis conditions using US or MW leads to different morphologies and particles dispersion. Indeed, using US and water/DMF as a solvent (c) resulted in the roughness of the surface of ZnO which is due to the aggregation of nanoparticles of ZIF-8 formed, while in MW (d) conditions non-converted ZnO particles were clearly noticeable together with aggregated ZIF-8 confirming lower conversion rate in the case of MW. Using US and water as the solvent (e) leads to bigger ZIF-8 with particles size around 881 nm (e) [44]. Which is much bigger than their homologues prepared after applying the MW with particle size under 200 nm (f). US led to more dispersed particles. It seems also that water yielded the highest conversion which is logic as pure water is dissociating further the ZnO. In comparison with the materials synthesized in Meth/W (g,h) the particle size is under 284 nm in both conditions [47]. Moreover, better dispersed particles were seen when US is applied, which is logic due to the effect of ultrasonic irradiation.

The equilibrium adsorption capacity of ZnO@ZIF-8 for phosphate ions was investigated as a function of initial concentration (Fig. 6 ). It was observed that when the initial phosphate concentration increased from 1 to 50 mg/L, an increment in phosphate adsorption was noted. This pattern suggests that the active sites on the surface of the two adsorbents were gradually occupied with increasing phosphate concentration, and thus reached the state of saturation with a maximum adsorption capacity of 101.61 and 94.95 mg/g for ZnO@ZIF-8-US and ZnO@ZIF-8-MW, respectively. Compared to other used MOFs for phosphate uptake (Table 4), our materials showed significant results based on their adsorption capacity, which is better than pristine ZIF MOFs. While their adsorption efficiency is still lower than composites materials, which can be an opportunity for a further study using ZnO derived ZIF-8 composites for higher phosphate removal capability.

As evidenced by the fitting curves and isothermal parameters, the Sips model exhibited the best fit to the experimental results, showing higher correlation coefficient values compared to Langmuir and Freundlich. In addition, the adsorption capacities calculated from the Sips model were the most approximate to those found experimentally. The correspondence to Sips isotherm model suggests a heterogeneous distribution of phosphate ions at low concentrations simultaneously with monolayer phenomenon at high concentrations.

Fig. 8 displays the kinetic adsorption data on phosphate on ZnO@ZIF-8 by US and MW. For the two investigated adsorbents, the phosphate uptake rate was rapid during the initial contact time (60 min) and then progressively decreased to achieve equilibrium in 240 min. This apparent high initial rate is potentially due to the fact that a large number of free active sites are available in the early phases of phosphate-ZnO@ZIF-8 contact. As the adsorption time increases, the binding sites on the adsorbent surface are progressively filled with phosphate ions. Hence, the vacancy of adsorption sites decreases and, accordingly, the rate of phosphate adsorption becomes more protracted.

The adsorption kinetics were analyzed using the Pseudo-first order, Pseudo-second order and Avrami Fractional order models (Fig. 8, Table 5 ). The obtained results revealed that the Pseudo-second order and Avrami fractional order kinetic models provide the best description of the phosphate adsorption behavior, given their fit correlation coefficients which are higher than that of the pseudo-first-order. Furthermore, the Qe values calculated by the Avrami and pseudo-second order kinetic models were found to be approximately in agreement with those experimentally determined. The fractional order of the Avrami kinetic model stems from the complexity of the reaction mechanisms or the existence of more than one reaction pathway, as stated by Cestari et al. [56]. Additionally, the consistent agreement with the pseudo-second order model suggest a chemisorption as an adsorption behavior of the used adsorbents towards phosphate [57]. This can be further confirmed by the FTIR after adsorption of both materials (Fig. S1), the disappearance of the peaks at 1675 cm−1 in the spectrums of the materials after phosphate adsorption shows the creation of bonds between the composites and phosphate anions through the imidazole heterocycle creating a delocalization of the π electrons between the two nitrogen atoms and the carbon atom N–C–N, allowing the adsorption of these anions from the aqueous medium [58,59]. Furthermore, the EDX (Fig. S4 and S5) results showed the existence of phosphorus element after the adsorption confirming its uptake on the material.

The effect of temperature on phosphate adsorption on ZnO@ZIF-8 by US and MW adsorbents was performed to establish the thermodynamic properties of the comprehensive adsorption scheme. The obtained results are illustrated in Fig. 9 and the thermodynamic parameters are presented in Fig. 10 and Table 6 The temperature was found to be a critical factor influencing the adsorption isotherm; as the temperature increased, the adsorption capacity increased for both ZnO@ZIF-8 by US and MW. This observed trend may be due to the increased mobility and diffusion of phosphates into the adsorbents structure, which implies an endothermic nature of phosphate adsorption onto the used adsorbents [60]. Besides, the increase in temperature can generate a swelling effect in the internal structure of the adsorbents, resulting in additional permeation of phosphate ions. The thermodynamic adsorption process appears to be spontaneous and feasible for both adsorbents, given the negativity of the free energy of Gibbs. ΔG° is reversely related to temperature implying that at higher temperatures the adsorption process is more effective [61], in accordance with the adsorption results obtained in this study. Moreover, the endothermicity of the adsorption reaction is confirmed by the positive values of enthalpy ΔH°. Furthermore, the positive values of ΔS° imply an induced associated augmentation of the degree of randomness of the solid/liquid interface, with consequent structural alterations in the adsorbate/adsorbent system [62].

The effect of pH on P adsorption was studied in the range of 5–12. As it can be seen in Fig. 11 , the removal of phosphate was very low in the case of acidic pH, and this can be due to the fact that ZIF-8 is not stable at acidic pH [63]. Maximum adsorption occurred at neutral pH, and decreased with the increase of pH, with a slight difference between ZnO@ZIF-8 synthesized with US and MW, as the ultrasound generated materials showed better P adsorption in the studied range of pH. The decrease in phosphate removal efficiency in the basic conditions could be attributed to the competition between P− and OH– ions especially in higher pH [24].

Moreover, a study of the influence of coexisting anions on phosphate adsorption was conducted using 100 mg/L of sulfate, chloride, nitrate and bicarbonate anions. As demonstrated in Fig. 12 , the influence of the applied anions other than chloride and nitrate is negligible for the selected concentration, implying that our adsorbents exhibited a strong selectivity toward phosphorus.

In this study, we reported the conversion of zinc oxide to ZIF-8 in different solvents mixtures assisted for the first time by US and MW. The different characterizations showed higher conversion rate in the case of US synthesized composites as the ultrasound irradiation allow the reaction to occur better between 2-MIM and ZnO. In addition, the SEM images showed a difference in the morphology of the prepared composites with respect to solvent mixture. A roughness of the surface of ZnO is showed in the case of Water/DMF in US due to the aggregation of nanoparticles of ZIF-8 formed, while in MW conditions non-converted ZnO particles were clearly noticeable together with aggregated ZIF-8. While using water as solvent in US conditions leads to bigger ZIF-8 with particles size around 881 nm which is much bigger than their homologues prepared by MW with particle size under 200 nm; lastly in the case of the mixture of MeOH/Water the particles size was under 284 nm for both US and MW. Moreover, the two materials prepared in Water/DMF were used as adsorbent for the phosphate removal. Different parameters were studied in detail such as adsorption time, adsorbate concentration, temperature, pH and competing ions effect showing that the sample prepared from US present a higher adsorption rate than its homologue prepared using MW. The current work would initiate further work on the conversion of other inorganic solid matters to different MOFs using US and MW.

Samit El Hankari; Conceptualization, writing, Data curation, review/editing, Supervision, Loubna Bazzi; Work lab, Data curation, Writing – original draft, writing-review/editing, Ikrame Ayouch; Data curation, writing-review/editing, Hamza Tachallait; Synthesis of material.
